Posts.Content: Footsox6 wrote: I am not sure this is the right place to post this. I had bilateral mastectomies last June, lymph nodes removed - 10 on the left and 2 on the right. My chest, and underarms still feel totally crappy. My armpits are still numb for the most part. I feel like someone has tied a rope tight around my chest and it is pinching under my arms. Does anyone else's incisions feel like this? Does it ever get better? I have been doing stretching exercises since right after surgery. I have a pretty good ramge of motion in my arms, but when I raise both arms straight over my head there is such a tightness under my arms. I am so fed up with it feeling this way. I am wondering if it is my crummy surgeon (who gave me really bad incisions) or does everyone's incisions feel this way for this long? I am now 8 months after surgery. Please tell me how your incisions feel 8 months or a year or so later. I am very depressed about this. Thanks for your help and telling me how your chest feels months after surgery. Yolanda Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: After Surgery - How long incisions feel bad? Footsox6 otter

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2009 03:23PM Footsox6 wrote: Hi Cyndi.  I know exactly what you mean.  I have lymphedema and am overweight.  From everything I have found out - being at an idea weight is much better for your lymphedema.  I had posted a similar question on the boards months ago, and I was hoping to find someone with lymphedema who actually had lost a lot of weight and how it reallly effected their lymphedema.  No one posted that they had actually lost a great deal of weight.  Perhaps someone will post this time.  The good news is that I have started the Nutrisystem diet and have lost 10 lbs.  So, perhaps I will lbe the "guinea pig' and be able to tell you for real in a few months, if the "skinnier me" has less lymphedema or only slightly less or what.  Stay tuned.... Yolanda
Posts.Title: Weight Loss & Exercise ck55 NatsFan

Posts.Content: Footsox6 wrote: I read a recommendation about a bosum buddy brand prosthesis and am thinking about ordering them.  Does anyone have them and can tell me about the shape of them?  They have round or teardrop shapes on their website.  I can't figure out if the teardrop shape extends somewhat under your arm or if it extends upward toward your bra strap?  Is it a horizontal teardrop or a vertical teardrop?  I will be using these in a pocketed bra and am trying to figure out if I need the round shape or what will slide into the pocket.  I have simple foam forms right now but they don't seem to extend under my arm the way my normal breast would.  If anyone has the bosum buddy breast forms, please give me some advice on what shape you have and how it fits.  Thanks for your help. Yolanda Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Bosom Buddy Prosthesis? Footsox6 Sassa

Posts.Content: Footsox6 wrote: Hi guys - I hate to post more about flying but I am really nervous about our 11 hour flight to Europe and I want to make sure I do everything right to avoid any problems.  In an earlier thread, some of you recommended I get full gloves for both hands for the flight.(and I will wear both sleeves as well)   I am making an appointment today to get measured for 2 custom gloves.  (I usually wear a gauntlet on one hand only)  So, I am now down to figuring out which brand and what level of compression I should order.  Any thoughts?  I know there are different levels of compression, but I am not very educated on it.  Is there some chart regarding the different levels of compression, which might explain the different types for me?  Or can someone just tell me what I should order for these full gloves for the flight?  I am kind of an over-killl type of person, so I want to make absolutely sure these limbs are compressed enough on this flight that I have a very slight chance of problems.  Thank you so much for your help.  You guys are great,  Yolanda Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Juzo or Jobst compression for flying? Footsox6 Footsox6

Posts.Content: Footsox6 wrote: I was diagnosed with breast cancer and had bilateral mastectomies last June (2007). I also had lymph nodes removed (2 were positive). I have now made it through chemo and am hoping to get back to normal now (a little more hair would be nice). I have this tickle in my throat and sometimes a slight tickle cough. I have had it for about 3 months. Could this be a sign of lung cancer? It is definitely not like a cold or flu. It is definitely not a hacking cough or a deep cough. And it only tickles me maybe once a day, but it is definitely there. Has anyone experienced this? I had a CT scan done before the chemo, in July. Wouldn't they have found something then? I will see the doctor next week and will bring it up then. I was just wondering if anyone else has expericned this. Thanks so much for any info or insight. Yolanda Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Breast cancer - now lung cancer? Footsox6 KiminJax

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2008 02:13PM Footsox6 wrote: Thanks for some calming replies. I appreciate it. I am hoping someone who has had breast cancer that turned into lung cancer will see this post and reply as to how they found out about their lung cancer. Perhaps it was some scan or maybe they had the same symptoms. I hope someone like that will post here. I know that we are all kind of paranoid about other cancers, but this is a strange cough/tickle thing, so that's why I am figuring it out. Hopefully I will get more replies. Thanks so much! Yolanda
Posts.Title: Breast cancer - now lung cancer? Footsox6 KiminJax

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2009 06:18PM Footsox6 wrote: Hi Kira - Wow.  Thanks.  So much great information.  I have an appointment to be measured tomorrow and I will talk to them about all this and see what they think.  I have found out that my "prefectionist measuring person" has left the therapy place I was going to, so I am a little sad about that.  Hopefully, the person I have to measure me tomorrow will be as meticulous.  I'll keep my fingers crossed.  Thank you for all your help and such great information.  I truly appreciate it!  Yolanda
